settings.heading: PPE for Construction
settings.heading1: That Works as Hard as You Do
settings.sub_heading: Equip your crew with certified, durable, and comfortable PPE—engineered for compliance and built for the toughest job sites across the USA.

settings.heading: U.S. Construction Industry Overview
settings.description1: The construction industry is a cornerstone of the American economy. As of 2024, the sector employs over 8.1 million workers and contributes approximately $2.1 trillion annually to the U.S. GDP. From residential builds and commercial skyscrapers to public infrastructure and renewable energy projects, construction is booming—but it also remains one of the most dangerous industries in the country.
settings.description2: According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, construction consistently ranks in the top five for workplace injuries and fatalities. In 2022 alone, there were over 169,000 nonfatal injuries and over 1,000 fatalities reported in construction. The top causes? Falls, struck-by objects, electrocutions, and caught-in/between incidents—most of which are preventable with the proper Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).

settings.description1:
Why a Trusted PPE Partner Matters

The utilities sector provides the backbone of modern life—delivering energy to over 145 million Americans through powerlines, substations, and underground cables. From storm restoration and grid maintenance to high-voltage installations, utility workers perform some of the most critical and dangerous jobs in the U.S.

The Electrical Safety Foundation International (ESFI) reports a steady rise in electrical fatalities, particularly in construction and repair roles. Workers in this sector face an ever-present risk of arc flash, electric shock, falls, and thermal burns, especially when working at height or under time pressure in post-disaster recovery.
settings.description2:
BLS data shows:

  • Over 50% of fatal electrical injuries occur during repair or construction
  • Nearly 1 in 3 utility worker injuries involve electrical burns or falls
  • Arc flash explosions can reach 35,000°F and occur in less than 1 second

In this high-stakes industry, proper PPE can mean the difference between survival and tragedy.

settings.description:
U.S. Oil & Gas Industry Overview

The oil and gas industry is the lifeblood of the American economy—powering homes, vehicles, and businesses. It employs over 600,000 workers across upstream exploration, midstream transportation, and downstream refining. From shale fields in Texas to deepwater operations in the Gulf of Mexico, this sector is driven by innovation—but defined by danger.

According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, oil and gas consistently rank among the top industries for workplace fatalities, largely due to explosions, toxic chemical exposure, electrical hazards, and confined space entry. Even minor errors can lead to catastrophic results, making proper PPE not just a regulatory requirement—but a literal life-saver.

Workforce realities in oil & gas:

  • High turnover and contract-based crews require fast onboarding and easy-to-use PPE
  • Harsh climates, remote locations, and flammable environments are standard
  • One PPE failure can result in site shutdowns, fines, or tragedy

The Critical Role of PPE in Construction Safety

PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) is the last line of defense between a worker and serious injury—or worse. From hard hats and steel-toe boots to fall arrest harnesses and high-vis apparel, PPE saves lives every single day.

Some key stats that highlight the importance of PPE:

  • 60% of workers involved in eye injuries were not wearing any eye protection at the time of the incident (CDC).
  • According to OSHA, 70% of hand injuries could be prevented with proper gloves.
  • In cases where PPE was used improperly, nearly 80% of the injuries were due to failure to wear it correctly or consistently.

These numbers underscore one truth:|PPE only works if it’s high-quality, properly selected, and consistently used.

The Critical Role of PPE in Electrical Safety
settings.sub_heading: PPE in this field is not a suggestion—it’s a requirement. Equipment must be certified, arc-rated, and layered appropriately to withstand electrical hazards, protect against thermal energy, and enable mobility during high-risk tasks like pole climbing or transformer repair.
settings.sub_heading1: Common risks mitigated with proper PPE:

settings.custom_description: Hard hats, bump caps, impact-resistant helmets
Harnesses, lanyards, climbing belts for elevated work

Why GE PPE is Your Ideal PPE Partner

settings.question: What PPE do I need to equip my construction crew with to stay compliant with safety regulations?
settings.answer: Many of our clients worry about meeting OSHA and local safety requirements. We help you navigate these regulations by recommending PPE tailored to your site’s hazards—from hard hats and fall protection to cut-resistant gloves and hearing protection—ensuring full compliance and peace of mind.

settings.question: How can I be sure your PPE meets safety standards and certifications?
settings.answer: A common concern is purchasing sub-par gear that won’t hold up to inspections. All our PPE products are tested and certified to meet or exceed ANSI/OSHA standards, and we provide documentation so you’re covered during audits or compliance checks.

settings.question: How do I choose the right PPE for specific tasks on my job site?
settings.answer: Clients often ask us how to avoid under- or over-equipping their teams. We offer task-specific recommendations and risk assessment support to make sure you get the right level of protection—nothing more or less than what you need.

settings.question: Is your PPE comfortable enough for long shifts in extreme conditions?
settings.answer: Discomfort leads to non-compliance. That’s why we design PPE with breathable, lightweight, and ergonomic materials, ensuring workers wear it properly—even during hot summers or long hours.

settings.question: Can your PPE handle rugged use and harsh job site environments?
settings.answer: Construction sites are tough, and so is our gear. Our clients look for durability and longevity, which is why our products are built with reinforced stitching, puncture-resistant materials, and weatherproof coatings that stand up to real-world conditions.

settings.question: Do you offer bulk pricing or support for outfitting entire crews?
settings.answer: Budget is a big concern for contractors. We offer bulk purchase options, site-wide outfitting packages, and custom pricing to help you equip your team affordably without sacrificing safety.

settings.question: What’s the turnaround time for orders—can I get PPE fast?
settings.answer: When new projects pop up or inspections are looming, speed matters. We maintain a robust inventory and offer fast shipping and rush fulfillment options to keep your job site running without delay.

settings.question: Do you offer branded or customized PPE for my crew?
settings.answer: Clients love promoting their brand while keeping teams safe. We offer custom logo printing and color options on a range of PPE items—from vests to hard hats—without compromising safety or certifications.

settings.question: Can you help us train our team on how to use and maintain PPE correctly?
settings.answer: A major pain point is improper use of gear. We provide user guides, on-site safety posters, and virtual training resources so your team knows how to wear, care for, and inspect PPE correctly.

settings.question: What support do you offer post-purchase?
settings.answer: Our relationship doesn’t end at checkout. We offer ongoing support, easy reordering options, and product updates, so your PPE program stays efficient, compliant, and up to date.

Safety Is Non-Negotiable
settings.description:
The construction industry is growing, but so is the scrutiny around safety. With billions of dollars riding on timely project completion and a human life behind every hard hat, investing in a trusted PPE supplier is not just smart business —it’s a moral and strategic imperative.

If you’re building something that lasts, your safety program—and your PPE partner—should be built to last, too.
